abstracts.cdata!:
This report demonstrates that almost the
            entire indigenous population found in the rural areas of 41
            selected municipalities have been consulted and widely
            participated in the project components of the Guatemala
            Western Altiplano Natural Resources Management Project. This
            report identifies the Constitutional laws and particularly,
            the Peace Accord provisions formulated in 1996, which
            guarantee that indigenous populations of rural areas be
            given security of land tenancy as a basis for improving
            their well-being and guaranteeing their liberty and dignity.
            The Convention for the International Labor Organization and
            other international agreements contain provisions
            recognizing the right of indigenous peoples to ownership and
            possession of lands traditionally belonging to them as well
            as allocating resources to help them develop institutions
            that will help them preserve and maintain indigenous
            knowledge, innovations, and practices that conserve and use
            community biodiversity in a sustainable way. The general
            strategy for indigenous participation a) incorporates and
            strengthens community organizations/participation at all
            levels--municipal and regional--and communicates with
            indigenous peoples in their own languages, and in their own
            cultural and spiritual idioms and using their own spokesmen;
            b) at the local level, relies on and strengthens local
            government entities (alcaldias auxiliaries and directives
            communitarias) so that each community's interests will
            be legally represented; c) at the municipal level, fosters
            the participation of local representatives from civil
            society with municipal representatives to ensure the best
            use of resources; and d) at the regional level, recommends
            the structure of an association of municipalities, such as
            an association of mayors from the project area, where every
            department affected by the project has as a member a
            permanent representative from each locality. Bilingual
            indigenous interpreters should participate with each
            association formed for a department. Consensus at the
            municipal level as well as at the regional level is the
            abiding principle guaranteeing participation in implementing
            the project.
